Award.AwardTitle: Experimental Investigations of the Contact Freezing Properties of Mineral Particles Using Optical Tweezers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Environmental Chemical Sciences Program in the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation supports the research of Professor Ryan Sullivan at Carnegie-Mellon who will determine the contact freezing properties of atmospherically relevant mineral particle compositions using optical tweezers. Professor Sullivan and his students will determine the ability of various types of mineral dust particles to catalyze the spontaneous heterogeneous freezing of supercooled droplets through contact freezing. The droplets will be suspended in a focus laser beam using a refrigerated optical tweezers system. The retrieved Raman spectrum will provide key information on the droplet?s physical and chemical state just prior to and when freezing occurs. The number of dust particle-droplet collisions that occur before freezing will be explicitly known, and contact freezing will also be discriminated from immersion freezing mechanisms. This research will help to resolve long outstanding questions regarding the prevalence of contact freezing in the atmosphere, and its potential importance for modifying cloud properties and inducing precipitation.

The proposed research will help fill an important knowledge gap regarding a fundamental phase transition of a ubiquitous molecule in our environment: water. The results will impact a wide range of fields from physical chemistry to biogeochemistry and atmospheric science, and increase our understanding of aerosols-cloud-climate interactions. The findings will be particularly important for improving the outdated descriptions of heterogeneous ice nucleation currently used in weather forecast and global climate models. The project will provide students with valuable experience in the novel use of optical tweezers to study heterogeneous ice nucleation for the first time. Our international collaboration with scientists at the University of Bristol will afford our students with the unique opportunity to be trained by experts in the use of optical tweezers for atmospheric aerosol particle research. The project will provide training opportunities for students in a research area of great societal importance.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project focused on the ability of atmospheric particles to catalyze the freezing of supercooled cloud droplets that do not freeze on their own until - 40 C. Two new aerosol optical tweezers systems were developed that allow us to trap individual droplets and observe how their chemical properties change using the droplet's cavity enhanced Raman spectrum produced by the trapping laser. We demonstrated the first optical tweezing of supercooled droplets under ice supersaturated conditions down to -20 C. Particle-droplet collisions can also be directly observed from the perturbation these events cause in the droplet's Raman spectrum. This has resulted in a new experimental method to study the contact freezing mechanism, the most uncertain and challenging to experimentally observe of all the heterogeneous ice nucleation mechanisms.

The second aerosol optical tweezers system allows us to generate in situ the tweezing chamber complex secondary organic aerosol material from the oxidation of terpenes and other organic vapors. These oxidation products then condense onto a tweezed droplet and analysis of the droplet's Raman spectrum enables us to determine the droplet's morphology and observe liquid-liquid phase separations. Along with the other particle properties we retrieve such as surface tension, diffusivity, viscosity, refractive index, and volatility, we gained much deeper insights into the critical chemical and physical properties that dictate the behavior and environmental impacts of mixed organic-aqueous inorganic particles in the atmosphere that often experience liquid-liquid phase separations. This dramatically alters the interactions of the droplet with its gas-phase environment as the particle's morphology dictates what components are present at the particle-air interface.

Evaluating the new droplet freezing cold plate system developed through this project revealed that the commonly used Snomax bacterial particle's ice nucleation properties are unstable and prone to degradation over storage and handling time. We hypothesize that this is due to deterioration of the largest protein aggregates that compose the most ice-active ice nucleants. This provides new insights into the nature of biological ice nucleating macromolecules, and also creates a need for caution in using biological particle systems as ice nucleation particle standards.

A new heterogeneous ice nucleation framework was developed based on our hypothesis of a critical particle surface area threshold. Below this threshold further decreases in particle surface area cause substantial broadening of the droplet freezing temperature spectrum. This results in apparently larger values of the ice active site surface densities retrieved from droplet freezing experiments, but this effect isn't accounted for by commonly used metrics to describe the ice nucleation properties of atmospheric particles. We can accurately predict the complex behavior of these droplet freezing spectra as the particle concentration and surface area are changed, allowing us to reliably extrapolate the experimental ice nucleation results to atmospheric cloud conditions where each cloud droplet contains just one particle.
